text.front:
Short Communications
DOI: 10.1002/zaac.200700528
Crystal Structure and Disorder Phenomena of the Adduct of Neutral C 60 and
the Ionic Gold Complex (Ptol 3 ) 2 AuNO 3
Martin Schulz-Dobrick and Martin Jansen*
Stuttgart, Max Planck Institute for Solid State Research, Germany
Received November 26th, 2007.
Abstract. The adduct C 60 • (Ptol 3 ) 2 AuNO 3 has been crystallized
from toluene solutions of C 60 and (Ptol 3 ) 2 AuNO 3 as violet, trigonal
plate-shaped crystals. The compound was studied by single-crystal
x-ray diffraction (P31c, a ϭ 1278.17(3), c ϭ 2282.92(6) pm). The
gold complex is dissociated into [(Ptol 3 ) 2 Au] ϩ cations, which
encapsulate the neutral C 60 molecules, and nitrate anions. The in-
termolecular interactions between the fullerene molecules and the
text.body:
Since the discovery of fullerenes [1] and their interesting electronic
and magnetic properties [2, 3], there has also been a considerable
interest in their supramolecular chemistry. Due to their electron
accepting properties, fullerenes interact and form co-crystals with
electron donor molecules that can adapt to the spherical shape of
the fullerenes. Examples include porphyrins, calixarenes and
molecules with aromatic donors [4Ϫ8]. The crystal chemistry of
C 60 and its co-crystals has been recently reviewed [9, 10].
The adaption to the spherical shape of the C 60 molecules may be
either realized by molecules with concave surfaces or the organiz-
ation of small donors into networks of concave shape. Depending
on the flexibility of the molecules or the networks, respectively, a
structure with optimal donor-acceptor interaction is possible. For
example phenol as a co-crystallizing agent is able to form highly
flexible supramolecular arrangements, which can encapsulate
fullerene molecules to form well-ordered compounds [11, 12]. In
this work, the synthesis and crystal structure of the adduct of neu-
tral C 60 with an ionic compound, the gold complex (Ptol 3 ) 2 AuNO 3
(tol: tolyl, -C 6 H 4 CH 3 ), is described and analyzed with respect to
the encapsulation and ordering of the fullerene molecules.
Results and Discussion
C 60 • (Ptol 3 ) 2 AuNO 3 precipitates from a solution of C 60 and
(Ptol 3 ) 2 AuNO 3 in toluene as violet, trigonal plate-shaped crystals.
The compound, once formed, is insoluble in toluene, which
accounts for a relatively high stability of the adduct. Growing
C 60 • (Ptol 3 ) 2 AuNO 3 from a rather diluted solution leads to larger

text.front:
Z. Anorg. Allg. Chem. 2008, 634, 817Ϫ819
© 2008 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
817
gold complex cations and the resulting disorder is investigated. The
crystal structure of C 60 • (Ptol 3 ) 2 AuNO 3 is providing an instructive
example, demonstrating that symmetry-matching is not always
sufficient for avoiding disorder.
Keywords: Fullerenes; Gold; Co-crystals; Solid-state structures;
Supramolecular chemistry; Crystal engineering
text.body:
and less intergrown crystals. The crystal structure was determined
by single crystal x-ray diffraction.
C 60 • (Ptol 3 ) 2 AuNO 3 crystallizes with trigonal symmetry and two
formula units in the unit cell. The gold complex is dissociated into
the linear [(Ptol 3 ) 2 Au] ϩ cation and the nitrate anion. In the crystal
structure, the cations are forming strands along [001] with the
supramolecular motif of sixfold phenyl embraces [13], i.e. six
C-H/π interactions between the tolyl-rings (see figure 1b). These
strands are in a hexagonal arrangement, as depicted in figure 1c.
In every hexagonal layer of the [(Ptol 3 ) 2 Au] ϩ cations, there are two
different kinds of voids. The small voids are occupied by the nitrate
ions and the large voids are occupied by the fullerene molecules.
In consecutive layers, the position of the small and large voids in-
terchange, as the [(Ptol 3 ) 2 Au] ϩ cations in are rotated by 60°. The
nitrate anions are disordered over several orientations, which could
not be resolved unambiguously.
The center of the C 60 molecule resides on the special position (2c,
2/3, 1/3, 3/4) with site symmetry 3.2. The molecule was found to
be disordered over two orientations, which are related by the crys-
tallographic twofold axes (figure 1a). All split positions could be
refined individually. It is interesting to ask why the C 60 molecule is
disordered, because the site symmetry of the void (3.2), which is
formed by the [(Ptol 3 ) 2 Au] ϩ cations, is a subgroup of the icosahed-
ral symmetry of C 60 . Thus, the C 60 molecule could in principle
be ordered in the crystal structure, but this unique orientation is
obviously not energetically favored. In order to further investigate
this phenomenon, an ordered model was constructed by rotating
the C 60 molecule until the crystallographic and the molecular two-
fold axes match and then the interaction with the surrounding tolyl
rings in the disordered and ordered model was examined. In the
resulting orientation, each fullerene is interacting with six tolyl
rings via π-π interactions and six additional tolyl rings via C-H/π
interactions. All of the six respective interactions are crystallo-
graphically equivalent, c.f. figure 2. In the disordered model, as
found experimentally, the hydrogen atom involved in the C-H/π
interaction points towards the center a hexagon and the border of
hexagon, respectively. In other words, every C 60 molecule is coordi-
nated by three hydrogen atoms pointing towards the center and

three hydrogen atoms pointing towards the border of a hexagon.
In the constructed, ordered model all hydrogen atoms are pointing
towards a 5:6 ring junction. The C-H/π interaction with the hexa-
gons is more favorable than with the pentagons, as the electron
density in the pentagons is lower [14]. Therefore, the overall C-H/
π interactions seem to be more efficient with the C 60 molecule in
the position of the disordered model compared to the ordered one.
The same conclusions can be drawn by looking at the π-π interac-
tions (figure 2c and d). According to the Hunter-Sanders rules [15],
the most favorable interaction should be between the π-electrons
of the tolyl-rings and the electron-poor 5:6 bonds of C 60 . In the
hypothetical ordered model, the tolyl-rings cover two 5:6 bonds
and two 6:6 bonds. In the disordered model, half of the tolyl-rings
cover two 5:6 bonds and two 6:6 bonds as well. The other half
covers four 5:6 bonds, so that this orientation of the C 60 molecule
should be slightly favored.
Figure 1 a) The two orientations of C 60 are depicted in green and
red. The view is along [1Ϫ10], which is parallel to the crystallo-
graphic twofold axis that is marked by the blue circle and relates
the two orientations. b) Visualization of the strands along [001] of
the [(Ptol 3 ) 2 Au] ϩ cations. c) Projection of the crystal structure
along [001]. Purple: P, blue: N, red: O.
By the inspection of both, the C-H/π and the π-π interactions, it is
plausible that the orientation of the C 60 molecule of the disordered
model is preferred over the orientation in the ordered model. The
occurrence of the disorder is inevitable as there are two crystallo-
graphically equivalent orientations. The crystal structure of
C 60 • (Ptol 3 ) 2 AuNO 3 is an instructive example, demonstrating that
symmetry-matching is not always sufficient for avoiding disorder.
Figure 3 shows a comparison between the experimental and calcu-
lated powder x-ray diffractograms of C 60 • (Ptol 3 ) 2 AuNO 3 , which
approves the structural model and the purity of the synthesized
bulk sample.
text.note:
www.zaac.wiley-vch.de
© 2008 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim
Z. Anorg. Allg. Chem. 2008, 817Ϫ819
text.body:
Figure 2 Visualization of the C-H/π contacts (a and b) and π-π
contacts (c and d) between the phenyl ligands and the fullerene
molecules of the disordered (a and c) and the hypothetical, ordered
model (b and d). The dark blue ball represent the hydrogen atom
of the C-H/π contact. All projections are parallel to the shortest
distances between the fullerenes and the hydrogen atom or the π-
system, respectively.
Figure 3 Comparison of the experimental and calculated x-ray
diffractograms. The experimental room temperature cell parame-
ters were used in the calculated pattern.
Conclusions
The fullerene adduct C 60 • (Ptol 3 ) 2 AuNO 3 has been synthesized as
a single phase. In the crystal structure, the C 60 molecule is dis-
ordered over two orientations, although the symmetry of C 60 and
its specific crystal environment would allow for adopting a unique
orientation. The reason for the disorder was found in the coordi-
nation to the surrounding tolyl-rings and the enhanced C-H/π and
π-π interactions present in the disordered model.
The Adduct of Neutral C 60 and the Ionic Gold Complex (Ptol 3 ) 2 AuNO 3

Experimental Part
C 60 (0.011 mmol), Ptol 3 AuNO 3 (0.016 mmol) and Ptol 3
(0.018 mmol) were dissolved in toluene (50 ml). The solvent was
evaporated slowly over the period of one week. During this time,
violet, plate-shaped crystals had formed. The supernatant solution
was removed and the crystals were washed with acetone. Single
crystals were mounted on glass capillaries for single crystal x-ray
measurements at 100 K. A powder x-ray measurement was per-
formed on a Stoe PSD diffractometer using Cu-Kα-radiation.
Room temperature unit cell parameters were determined by the Le
Bail-method: a ϭ 12.7817(3) Å , c ϭ 22.8292(6) Å , R p ϭ 0.044. The
IR spectrum (KBr pellet) can be attributed to the constituting spec-
ies. C 60 : 1428w, 1182w, 579w, 527m, NO 3
Ϫ : 1333s, (Ptol 3 ) 2 Au ϩ :
1549m, 1496m, 1444w, 1397w, 1384w, 1308m, 1262w, 1190w, 1102s,
1017w, 848w, 813s, 731w, 707w, 649m, 615m, 508s (in cm Ϫ1 ).
The crystal structure was solved by the Patterson method and sub-
sequent difference fourier maps and refined on F 2 (Shelxtl). The
fullerene molecules are disordered over two orientations. All split-
positions have been refined individually without restraints. All
non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement
parameters. Hydrogen positions were calculated using the HFIX
command. The oxygen atoms of the nitrate ion were found to be

text.body:
disordered over 5 different positions (2 crystallographic sites) and
refined with isotropic parameters. Table 1 contains further details
of the refinement.
CCDC 668341 contains the supplementary crystallographic data
for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The
Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/
data request/cif.
